means: [人名] [英格兰人姓氏] 勒克 Lucas的变体

sameAnalysis.part_name: 这些名词均有"命运，运气"之意。
sameAnalysis.word_list: destiny, fate, lot, doom, luck, fortune
means: destiny ： 普通用词，侧重预先注定的命运，对未来命运的美好憧憬。
fate ： 较庄严用词，多指不幸的命运，暗示不可避免，令人畏惧和人的意志无法改变，宿命论色彩较浓。
lot ： 多指偶然的运气或终身遭受的不幸命运。
doom ： 指最终的，常常是灾难性或毁灭性的命运，隐含不可避免的意味。
luck ： 普通日常用词，指好的或坏的运气，尤多指好运气，有时也指成功或愉快的结局。
fortune ： 普通用词，指由机会或运气来决定的一种命运，如暗示一种比fate好的运气或一种愉快的未来。

sentence.Network_en: Good luck is when an opportunity comes along and you're prepared for it.
sentence.Network_cn: 好运就是当机会来临时，你早已做好了准备。

sentence.Network_en: He does deserve some good luck after so much wretchedness.
sentence.Network_cn: 经过这么多苦难之后，他应该行点好运了。

sentence.Network_en: Wood has not had much luck in carving out a career.
sentence.Network_cn: 伍德想干出点名堂来，可是总不能如愿。

jx.jx_en_mean: used to indicate the fortuitousness of a situation

lj.lj_ly: as luck would have it, his route took him very near where they lived.
lj.lj_ls: 碰巧他走的路线离他们的住所很近。

jx.jx_cn_mean: 为了吉利；为了祈求好运

lj.lj_ly: I wear this crystal under my costume for luck.
lj.lj_ls: 我贴身戴着块水晶，希望它能带给我好运。

jx.jx_en_mean: used to express wishes for success
the outcome of chance rather than something one can control

lj.lj_ly: quality of care depends largely on the luck of the draw.
lj.lj_ls: 照料的好坏在很大程度上取决于运气。

jx.jx_en_mean: (informal)used to express disappointment that something has not happened or is unlikely to happen
let favourable events take their course without taking undue risks
do something that involves risk or luck, hoping to succeed

lj.lj_ly: he thought he'd &B{try his luck at} farming in Canada.
lj.lj_ls: 他想碰碰运气去加拿大办农场。

phrase.cizu_name: with (any 或 a bit of) luck

jx.jx_en_mean: expressing the hope that something will happen in the way described

lj.lj_ly: with luck we should be there in time for breakfast.
lj.lj_ls: 如果一切顺利的话，我们可以到达那里赶上吃早餐。

lj.lj_ly: I have to go to secretarial school, worse luck.
lj.lj_ls: 不幸的是，我不得不去秘书学校。

jx.jx_cn_mean: 幸运的：享受成功的；幸运的

derivation.yuyuan_name: late Middle English (as a verb): perhaps from Middle Low German or Middle Dutch lucken. The noun use (late 15th cent.) is from Middle Low German lucke, related to Dutch geluk, German Glück, of West Germanic origin and possibly related to lock

entry.def: Luck or good luck is success or good things that happen to you, that do not come from your own abilities or efforts.

example.ex: I knew I needed a bit of luck to win...
example.tran: 我知道自己要赢需要点运气。

example.ex: The Sri Lankans have been having no luck with the weather...
example.tran: 斯里兰卡人在天气方面运气一直很差。

entry.def: Bad luck is lack of success or bad things that happen to you, that have not been caused by yourself or other people.

example.ex: I had a lot of bad luck during the first half of this season...
example.tran: 上半赛季我一直走背运。

example.ex: Randall's illness was only bad luck.
example.tran: 兰德尔生病纯粹是时运不济。

entry.def: If you ask someone the question 'Any luck?' or 'No luck?', you want to know if they have been successful in something they were trying to do.
You can say 'Bad luck', or 'Hard luck', to someone when you want to express sympathy to them.

entry.tran: 带来霉运/带来好运；不吉利/ 吉利
entry.def: If you say that something brings bad luck or brings someone good luck, you believe that it has an influence on whether good or bad things happen to them.

example.ex: Jean was extremely superstitious and believed the colour green brought bad luck.
example.tran: 琼十分迷信，她认为绿色不吉利。

entry.tran: （常指因缺钱而）遭遇厄运，时运不济
entry.def: If you describe someone as down on their luck, you mean that they have had bad experiences, often because they do not have enough money.

entry.tran: 碰巧的运气；运气的结果
entry.def: If you say that something is the luck of the draw, you mean that it is the result of chance and you cannot do anything about it.

example.ex: The luck of the draw meant the young lad had to face one of America's best players.
example.tran: 完全是运气使然，这位小伙子必须面对一位美国一流选手。

entry.def: If you say 'Good luck' or 'Best of luck' to someone, you are telling them that you hope they will be successful in something they are trying to do.

example.ex: He kissed her on the cheek. 'Best of luck!'
example.tran: 他吻了吻她的脸颊。“祝你好运！”

entry.def: You can say someone is in luck when they are in a situation where they can have what they want or need.

example.ex: You're in luck. The doctor's still in.

entry.def: If you say it is just your luck that something unpleasant has happened to you, you mean that this is quite normal because unpleasant things are always happening to you.

example.ex: It would be just his luck to miss the last boat.
example.tran: 他就这运气，误了最后一班船也毫不出奇。

entry.tran: 运气不好；不走运；不凑巧
entry.def: If you say that someone is out of luck, you mean that they cannot have something which they can normally have.

example.ex: 'What do you want, Roy? If it's  money, you're out of luck.'
example.tran: “你想要什么，罗伊？要钱的话，那你别指望了。”

entry.def: You can say 'No such luck' when you want to express your disappointment over something.

example.ex: He must have been hoping for a relaxed time. No such luck.
example.tran: 他一定是一直想放松一段时间，可就是没这个命。

entry.tran: 得寸进尺；冒不明智的风险
entry.def: If you say that someone is pushing their luck, you think they are taking a bigger risk than is sensible, and may get into trouble.

example.ex: I didn't dare push my luck too far and did not ask them to sign statements.
example.tran: 我不敢太过贪心不足，没有要他们签署声明。

entry.tran: 受幸运之神眷顾；福星高照
entry.def: If you say that luck was on someone's side, you mean that they succeeded in something by chance as well as by their own efforts or ability.

example.ex: Rick seems to have had luck on his side during his 12-year acting career.
example.tran: 在12年的演艺生涯中，里克好像总有福星高照。

entry.def: If someone tries their luck at something, they try to succeed at it, often when it is very difficult or there is little chance of success.

example.ex: She was going to try her luck at the Las Vegas casinos.
example.tran: 她打算去拉斯韦加斯的赌场碰碰运气。

entry.tran: 希望；但愿；运气好的话；一切顺利的话
entry.def: You can add with luck or with any luck to a statement to indicate that you hope that a particular thing will happen.

example.ex: We'll have a long talk and a good cry and then with any luck  we'll both feel better.
example.tran: 我们会一席长谈，大哭一场，但愿这样我们两个都会好过一点。

means.word_mean: 1. your overall circumstances or condition in life (including everything that happens to you);
2. an unknown and unpredictable phenomenon that causes an event to result one way rather than another;

sentences.sentence: "we ran into each other by pure chance"

means.word_mean: 3. an unknown and unpredictable phenomenon that leads to a favorable outcome;

sentences.sentence: "it was my good luck to be there"
"it was as if fortune guided his hand"

list.explanation: 随意地，有啥吃啥(常指吃便饭)

example.en: Come on and dine pot luck.
Lots of luck in your new job!

list.explanation: [讽刺语]祝成功或好运(意味着你没希望的反语)

example.en: Think you stand a chance? Lots of luck!
example.zh: 你以为你有希望吗？祝你好运!

auth_sentence.content: I think we deserved a bit of luck today.
auth_sentence.res_content: I think we deserved a bit of luck today.
auth_sentence.res_content_con: I think we deserved a bit of luck today.

auth_sentence.content: But Mr Hollande's luck didn't end there.
auth_sentence.res_content: But Mr Hollande's luck didn't end there.
auth_sentence.res_content_con: But Mr Hollande's luck didn't end there.

auth_sentence.content: Good luck my friend, horse of a lifetime.
auth_sentence.res_content: Good luck my friend, horse of a lifetime.
auth_sentence.res_content_con: Good luck my friend, horse of a lifetime.

Sentence.sentence: While it may be common for university researchers to try their luck in the commercial world, there is very little traffic in the opposite direction.

jushi.chinese: 我简直不敢相信我的运气。

jushi.english: Some people refer all the troubles to bad luck instead of to lack of ability.
jushi.chinese: 有些人把自己所有的苦恼都归咎于运气不佳,而不认为是缺乏能力。

jushi.english: I hope this charm will bring luck to you.
jushi.chinese: 我希望这个符咒会给你带来好运。
